text: Love the demo placed right on the landing page :100:

text: It's not radically different from KidSim or PuzzleScript or other similar environments, but I really like that it works on a handheld, and the entire interface is basically a simple tile editor

elements.text: It's not radically different from KidSim or PuzzleScript or other similar environments, but I really like that it works on a handheld, and the entire interface is basically a simple tile editor

text: If I had the time I would have made a 3D version of something like this as a VR programming language

elements.text: If I had the time I would have made a 3D version of something like this as a VR programming language

text: maybe using angle and distance relationships instead of a discreet grid :grimacing:

elements.text: maybe using angle and distance relationships instead of a discreet grid

text:
>  The resolution for move and paint commands introduces the possibility of *non-deterministic* behavior in games. For example, if a move-left and move-right command are sent to the same sprite, the resolution will choose one of the two commands at random. This is useful for coding unpredictable non-player character behavior.
I like their approach to conflict resolution and that they explicitly state some commands can lead to non-determinism.  I actually think that for many game types determinism is overrated and their suggestion that you can exploit this as a feature (random selection of a move) is pretty cool.

Facebook Horizon runs actions in order of execution (last action to change state will be the final state) but choosing a random command for immediate actions might have been a cool feature.  I also thought about introducing priority to actions

behavior in games. For example, if a move-left and move-right command are sent to the same sprite, the resolution will choose one of the two commands at random. This is useful for coding unpredictable non-player character behavior.

I like their approach to conflict resolution and that they explicitly state some commands can lead to non-determinism.  I actually think that for many game types determinism is overrated and their suggestion that you can exploit this as a feature (random selection of a move) is pretty cool.

Facebook Horizon runs actions in order of execution (last action to change state will be the final state) but choosing a random command for immediate actions might have been a cool feature.  I also thought about introducing priority to actions

text: Love the use of term rewriting here. For some reason term rewriting + a game loop hadn’t crossed my mind.
